revision.text:
{{Infobox military person | name = Teme Sejko | image = TemeSejko.jpg | caption = Teme Sejko in Moscow during his studies | birth_date = {{Birth date|1922|08|25}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1961|05|31|1922|08|25}} | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial = | birth_place = [[Konispol]], [[Principality of Albania]] | death_place = [[People's Republic of Albania]] | placeofburial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | nickname = | birth_name = Teme Sejko | allegiance = [[Albanian Armed Forces]] | branch = [[Albanian navy]] | serviceyears = 1945-1960 | rank = [[rear-admiral]] | servicenumber = | unit = | commands = | battles = [[World War II]] | battles_label = | awards = | relations = | laterwork = }}
'''Teme Sejko''' (August 25, 1922 – May 31, 1961) was an [[Albanians|Albanian]] [[rear-admiral]] and commander of the [[Albanian navy]] and the naval base of [[Durrës]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Kalnins|first=Karlis|title=East Central Europe and the world: developments in the post-Stalin era|editor=Stephen Denis Kertesz|publisher=[[University of Notre Dame Press]]|year=1962|series=Notre dame university international studies|pages=207|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7I62AAAAIAAJ}}</ref> In 1961 he was executed for allegedly being the leader of a pro-Soviet group that had been planning a [[coup d'état]] against [[Enver Hoxha]] by selling the [[Albanian navy]] to the [[United States Sixth Fleet|Sixth Fleet]].
== Background == Teme Sejko, a member of the Sejko family of [[Filiates]], was born in [[Konispol]], [[Albania]], on August 25, 1922.<ref name=archive/><ref>http://lajme.shqiperia.com/lajme/artikull/iden/46441/titulli/Te-rrefesh-historine-tragjike-te-Teme-Sejkos</ref><ref>http://www.ndryshe.com/mat.php?idm=10827&l=a</ref> His father, Mehmet Sejko, was a landlord of the region. His mother, Shyqëranie Taka, was a housewife. She was the niece of [[Alush Taka]] who had been a commander of the [[Vlora War]]. Teme Sejko had two brothers, Taho and Sulo, and two sisters, Nurie and Merushe. One of his sisters was married to [[Rexhep Plaku]], a landlord from [[Konispol]]. His father sent Teme to [[Tiranë]], [[Sarandë]], and [[Shkodër]] to study. He finished his studies in the [[Voroshilov Military Academy of the USSR Army General Staff|Voroshilov Military Academy]] in [[Moscow]].<ref name=archive>[http://www.osaarchivum.org/files/holdings/300/8/3/text/1-6-71.shtml YUGOSLAV COMMENT ON TIRANA SPY TRIAL F-107], 1961, Open Archives, accessed April 2010</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Dismukes|first=Bradford|author2=James M. McConnell |title=Soviet naval diplomacy|publisher=Pergamon Press|year=1979|isbn=0-08-023906-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wiXFFDSpU9IC}}</ref>
== Activity in the Albanian army == In 1943 he was sent by the [[Military history of Albania during World War II|National Anti-Fascist Liberation Army of Albania]] to [[Konispol]], where he became one of the founding members of the [[Chameria battalion]] ({{lang-sq|Batalioni Çamëria}}). After [[World War II]] Teme Sejko rose rapidly through the ranks of the [[Albanian army]], becoming in 1958 [[rear-admiral]] of the [[Albanian navy]]. During the period of poor relations with Yugoslavia, Colonel Sejko was sending undercover groups into Yugoslavia.<ref name=archive/>
In July 1960 he was arrested by the [[Sigurimi]], Albania's secret police, for allegedly being part of a joint Greek-Yugoslav-Italian-US sixth Fleet counterrevolutionary plot to overthrow the Albanian government.<ref>Socialist Albania since 1944: domestic and foreign developments, Peter R. Prifti Edition illustrated Publisher MIT Press, 1978 ISBN 0-262-16070-6, ISBN 978-0-262-16070-4 Length 311 pages. ''page 206''</ref><ref>The Albanians: a modern history Author Miranda Vickers Edition 3, revised, illustrated, reprint Publisher I.B.Tauris, 1999 ISBN 1-86064-541-0, ISBN 978-1-86064-541-9 Length 282 pages. ''page 187''</ref> He was arrested along with six other military commanders: his brother, and ex-[[editor-in-chief]] of ''[[Zëri i Popullit]]'', [[Taho Sejko]]; [[Liri Belishova]], chairwoman of the Central Committee of the [[Party of Labour of Albania]]; and [[Tahir Demi]], representative of Albania at [[Comecon]]. They were tried in May 1961 and convicted. Teme Sejko was sentenced to death and shot after the trial along with three other high-ranking members of the Albanian army and the [[Party of Labour of Albania]], [[Tahir Demi]], [[Abdyl Resuli]] and [[Hajri Mane]] on 31 May 1961.<ref>{{cite book|others= Free Europe Committee|title=East Europe|publisher=East Europe Pub. Co.|year=1962|series=East Europe|volume=11|pages=20|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-1EvAAAAMAAJ}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|others=International Commission of Jurists (1952- )|title=Bulletin of the International Commission of Jurists|editor=International Commission of Jurists (1952- )|publisher=University of Michigan|year=1962|pages=7–8}}</ref> The four remaining commanders received prison sentences ranging from 15 years to [[life imprisonment]]. Teme Sejko's son, Sokol, and two of his brothers were shot as well. His wife, Shpresa, committed suicide as did his brother, Sulo. After his execution the [[Office of Naval Intelligence]] reported that Teme Sejko was a key figure of the [[History of Communist Albania#Albania and the Soviet Union|Soviet-Albanian split]]. Sources in Yugoslavia at the time argued that Sejko had been accused because of his politics. It was said that the executions had arisen because Hoxha disagreed with the conclusions of a Party conference in [[Tirana]] in 1956.<ref name=archive/>
== Sources == {{reflist}}
